top_comment.text:
I was born at a time when the Internet and the World Wide Web did not 
exist. There was only Black and White Analog Television, only AM (amplitude 
modulation) radio existed, Land Line (pulse dialing) rotor dialing phones, 
and large (room size) computers.

After you view the YouTube Video link below, please check out the 
additional two web links shown below.

YouTube - The Web is Not The Net

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=scWj1BMRHUA


Home of the world’s first website on the internet

http://info.cern.ch/


One second on the web

http://onesecond.designly.com/


10 years ago Skype, Facebook, YouTube, Reddit, Twitter, Tumblr, Dropbox, 
and Instagram didn't exist.

20 years ago there were only 130 websites total, Google wasn't even around 
yet, and you had to pay for an email account through an ISP.

30 years ago there was no internet.


#history   #technology   #worldwideweb  ﻿

comments.author: William DeMardes

comments.text:
Some of your info is pretty far off, some others just off be a year or two.

FM radio was invented 2 decades before you where born. It may not have been 
widely used in Nashville when you where born, but it was around for quite a 
while.

Color TV also predates you by a couple years. The fact that it wasn't 
common till much later is a cost and opportunity issue.

20 years ago from today would be 1995, by that time, MTSU and TTU had been 
on the internet for 2 years. I think Vandy was on even earlier. Hard to 
dispute the comment that you had to pay for email accounts. Telalink(an 
early Nashville ISP) gave you one account free with your dialup access in 
'96, at least according to the info on the wayback archive. So even in 
Nashville, it was unlikely you had to pay for the first email account. By 
the end of 1995, you had Yahoo and ebay on the internet. Also in '95, it is 
claimed that more email was sent/received than US postal mail.  

30 years ago puts us in 1985. That was a year that Cisco was building a 
router with IP only capabilities. IP being Internet Protocol.  TCP/IP has 
it's origins around 1973. DNS has it's origins around 1983. 

The video had it's own issues. The internet taking it's terms from the sea 
is just false after the fact justification. The term pirate being used 
outside of naval usage is common. In the 1940's it was used for radio 
stations even on the land. It had been used for software piracy long before 
we had common usage of the internet. 

The first person to use "Surfing the internet" was borrowing the term from 
channel surfing. And even then, it was being used for Gopher, the tool that 
was from before Tim Berners-Lee and HTML and therefore the "web".
comments.author: Steven Critchfield

comments.text:
+Moose Frenzy By that logic, every letter, number, and punctuation mark are 
pictures. I assume you don't know how to read Chinese, so consider a single 
Chinese character. To you, it would be nothing but a picture of strait and 
squiggly lines. But to someone who CAN read Chinese, they would know what 
that picture of strait and squiggly lines meant, and only because the 
person who first created it taught others what it meant.
Likewise, you DO know how to read English, but to a Chinese man, this 
entire comment is nothing more than a string of strait and squiggly lines. 
But you know what these strait and squiggly lines mean, because you were 
taught what each one means and what specific groups of them mean.
So, when I say the word "cat", you know what c, a, and t means. You also 
know what those three letters combined in that order means. So when you 
read "cat", you imagine a cat in your head. Where it gets tricky is what 
that cat looks like to you. It might be black, or orange. You may even come 
up with a simple personality for the cat. But if you were to write down 
every single detail of the cat you're imagining, then someone else could 
read what you wrote and see in their head exactly what you saw.
Except the Chinese man. He still sees a bunch of strait and squiggly lines.

comments.text:
+TheNecrofluff They don't seem like symbols to me it's clearly a language 
not a image; even hieroglyphics seem to be symbols/images purely because 
they are modeled after existing things but they are just another character. 
but some letters/characters can be seen as symbols when they actually stand 
for something other than a basic building block of a language.
An example would be something as simple as the word Hope or 死 (kanji for 
death). However this does compare to images like a peace sign.

        Going back to the roots using peace sign as an example, as word 
form the general thought is 2 options of imagery being a literal symbol 
with a circle sectioned off or one made with the hand, but simply because 
it is a word that is all it can bring.
With the images of either generalized options are expanded with the context 
of the rest of the image. The symbol of peace being shown in many way to 
represent the same as a word as well as a number of things whether it's a 
complete decade or monumental event like war. The hand sign can be seen in 
many ways as well including the hippie era, a treaty between countries, an 
insult to some (not even kidding), and simply a means of saying you are not 
hostile.

Oh and if you plan a response please make it finalized to your best extent 
as to be honest I'd rather not spend forever on just this topic haha.
comments.author: Moose Frenzy

comments.text:
+Moose Frenzy  For the "by ear" argument, I see what you're getting at, but 
isn't determining a note by ear simply like being able to understand words 
spoken? For some people "their", "they're" and "there" might sound the 
same, others can tell you what was said even without context.
I am not a musician myself, we only practised "listening notes" back in 
school. I think some people have it easier than others, but that it is a 
skill that can be learned. One might never be as good as it as someone with 
talent in that field, same as with painting for example, but in my opinion 
the basics can be learned.
Music notation is said to be "written symbols" and we must first "write 
music" for it to be read or played. But what is the difference between 
symbols and letters? Some might say that not all letters are symbols and 
not all symbols are letters. If we don't take the latin letter system but 
look for example at arabic letters, Hiragana or Kanji, they do seem a lot 
like symbols to the average person (who probably cannot read them).
I never thought it possible, but right now I'm genuinely interested in this 
topic :p
comments.author: TheNecrofluff

comments.text:
Deep Web is a catch-all term for all sorts. Websites tend to have way more 
pages than just the ones you can access; including php files, databases, 
javascript files, info/config files... all technically accessible through 
the internet but locked to everyone but the website admin(s). There are 
also millions of articles submitted to online academic journals, access to 
which has to be paid for. Not to mention other paid-content sites. There 
are other protocols other than http(s)/fps: I2P, P2P, Gopher, TOR, 
Freenet... all very much legal as a platform for swapping data and with 
their own pros and cons [apart from Gopher, which is mainly cons as it's 
difficult to search, pretty much text-only, and is only really used by 
hobbyists/enthusiasts [a.k.a: Buzz Killingtons : ) ]. The Internet isn't a 
dark, dangerous place; it's just people doing people stuff. I dislike all 
the fear behind it; it's a tool which can be used for so much, 
[subjectively] good and [subjectively] bad- like a hammer... or a sandwich! 
: )
comments.author: Jamie Carroll

comments.text:
As many have said, there is the deep web and there is the dark net. Most of 
the deep web is completely legal to access. Then we also have the dark net. 
The dark net is a term used to categorize those more seedy areas of the 
internet; for example, sites that you can view illegal pornography on, hire 
hitmen, etc. The communications and transactions usually on this are 
usually F2F(Friend to Friend) which means that they are often direct links 
between two computers over network infrastructure. However, these sites 
make up the minority of the deep web. As to the specific legality of 
visiting such sites, such as the Silk Road ([illegal] drug wholesaler), 
merely looking at these sites will not get you into legal trouble(maybe on 
a watch-list if you are not heavily obfuscated), but the moment that you 
order something or view something such as cp you WILL most likely be 
tracked down and charged with a crime. 

On to the lighter stuff. Many of the sites on the deep web operate on the 
old BBS system used during a good portion of the 90's. This is basically a 
system whereby there isn't really a search engine, but you look at a large 
list of sites and take a hyperlink to them from which you can travel onward.

To address +SuperSaiyanMaze 's question the way that you can access the 
deep web is not extremely difficult. A popular browser that is often 
utilized is The Onion Ring [TOR] browser; you can simply google this 
browser and you will find the TOR foundation's website where you can 
download it as a zip file. Once you open the browser, which is a modified 
version of Firefox, you can use a search engine such as DuckDuckGo or even 
Google and search something along the lines of "list of .onion website 
indexes."

As mentioned above many deep web websites have particular entrance 
requirements. Some of them require you to do a Captcha, others require 
passwords, memberships, use of specific protocols or scripts, contextual 
cues, et cetera.

My final word to all of you is one of caution. Things like the TOR browser 
don't completely mask your activity. If you do something illegal and aren't 
obfuscated enough law enforcement will eventually catch you. Bottom line, 
do not do something stupid.

By the way, thanks for the watchlist add NSA.

comments.text:
Level 0 - Common Web 
This level is the one you browse everyday : YouTube , Facebook, Wikipedia 
and other famous or easily accessible websites can be found here . 
Level 1 - Surface Web 

This level is still accessible through normal means , but contains " darker 
" websites, : such as 4chan . 
Level 2 - Bergie Web 

This level is the last one normally accessible : That all levels follow 
this one have to be accessed with a proxy , or by Tor modifyig your 
hardware . In this level you can find some " underground" but still indexed 
websites, : such as 4chan . 
Level 3 - Deep Web 

The first part of this level has to be accessed with a proxy . It contains 
CP , gore , hacking websites ... Here begins the Deep Web The second part 
of this level is only accessible through Tor , and blackberries contains 
sensible information . 
Level 4 - Charter Web 

Also this level is divided in two parts . The first can be accessed through 
Tor. Things : such as drug and human traficking , banned movies and books 
and black markets exist there . The second part can be accessed through a 
hardware modification : a "Closed Shell System " . Here , Becomes serious 
**** . This part of the Charter Web contains hardcore CP , experimental 
hardware information ( " Gadolinium Gallium Garnet Quantum Electronic 
Processors " ...) , but Also darker information , : such as the " Law of 
13" , World War 2 experiments , and even the location of Atlantis . The 
further you go into Charter Web , be weary of unmarked surveillance 
vehicles in your area of residence. 
Level 5 - Marianas WebEdit 

You'll be lucky to find anyone who knows about it . Probably secret 
government documentation 



Level 6 - ? - Intermediary between the Marianas Web , Level 7 and Level 8. 
Level 7 - The Fog / Virus Soup - The best way to describe this level is to 
a war zone . Its every man for himself down there . Everybody is trying to 
reach 8th level and Preventing others from coming in there . 

Level 8 - The Primarch System - Level 8 ... Level 8 is impossible to access 
directly. It is the system That controls the internet . No government, 
organization or person has control over it . Nobody even knows what it is . 
It sends out unalterable messages randomly to the entire Internet . Level 8 
is thought to be seperated by a "level 17 TR001 quantum level function lock 
" , wich is impossible for our computers to break . 
Lol , some people believe this bullshit ? 
Just some 4chan trolling .

Okay let's clear this all up because there's a lot of confusion.
The Web is like an ocean. What we normally use, accessible by browsers like 
Google, is the surface. The Deep Web is the rest of it, like the depths of 
the ocean. However, like these ocean depths, it is dark and hard to 
navigate. While the depths of the ocean are dark and home to mysterious 
animals and objects that can hurt you, it's mostly harmless. Same with the 
Deep Web. Most of it is sites protecting and storing passwords, boring 
sites protected by complex computer code. However, the rest of it, a tiny 
fraction that these people are talking about, is a very dangerous place, 
heaven for pedos, terrorists, and assassins. Of course because all the 
other sites of the Deep Web are useless, most people see the dangerous side 
of it.
The Deep Web has been used by rapists, terrorists teaching their children 
how to make bombs, and dealing crack. It has also been used for safer 
purposes such as government communication and by rebel groups in communist 
countries to plan revolutions and independence.
It can be accessed using TOR, but to be safe, I wouldn't go.

comments.text:
All right, I'll just post what I posted above

As many have said, there is the deep web and there is the dark net. Most of 
the deep web is completely legal to access. Then we also have the dark net. 
The dark net is a term used to categorize those more seedy areas of the 
internet; for example, sites that you can view illegal pornography on, hire 
hitmen, etc. The communications and transactions usually on this are 
usually F2F(Friend to Friend) which means that they are often direct links 
between two computers over network infrastructure. However, these sites 
make up the minority of the deep web. As to the specific legality of 
visiting such sites, such as the Silk Road ([illegal] drug wholesaler), 
merely looking at these sites will not get you into legal trouble(maybe on 
a watch-list if you are not heavily obfuscated), but the moment that you 
order something or view something such as cp you WILL most likely be 
tracked down and charged with a crime. 

On to the lighter stuff. Many of the sites on the deep web operate on the 
old BBS system used during a good portion of the 90's. This is basically a 
system whereby there isn't really a search engine, but you look at a large 
list of sites and take a hyperlink to them from which you can travel onward.

To address +SuperSaiyanMaze 's question the way that you can access the 
deep web is not extremely difficult. A popular browser that is often 
utilized is The Onion Ring [TOR] browser; you can simply google this 
browser and you will find the TOR foundation's website where you can 
download it as a zip file. Once you open the browser, which is a modified 
version of Firefox, you can use a search engine such as DuckDuckGo or even 
Google and search something along the lines of "list of .onion website 
indexes."

As mentioned above many deep web websites have particular entrance 
requirements. Some of them require you to do a Captcha, others require 
passwords, memberships, use of specific protocols or scripts, contextual 
cues, et cetera.

My final word to all of you is one of caution. Things like the TOR browser 
don't completely mask your activity. If you do something illegal and aren't 
obfuscated enough law enforcement will eventually catch you. Bottom line, 
do not do something stupid.

Also, hello NSA analyst reading this. Thank you for trying to determine if 
I'm a threat while also breaching my rights and possibly putting me on a 
watchlist.
comments.author: zucciniknife

comments.author: tehfutureawesome

comments.text:
+tehfutureawesome Each website could be "saved" somewhere entirely 
different to another. Web pages are "saved", to use your terms, on servers. 
Each server has its own unique IP address. Servers are basically just 
computers programmed to take requests and return things back out.

When you go to a web page by typing a URL, that name has to be converted 
into an IP. Each domain name can have a different IP address associated 
with it. When you try to go to a webpage, there are specific servers called 
"Domain Name Servers", or DNS, that convert the Domain name into it's IP so 
your data can be sent to the right place.

When you make a request to see a web page, the source (yours) and 
destination (the server's) IPs are attached to your request. Your request 
travels through networks, making paths through the internet until it 
reaches the server where the specific web page is "saved".

The server can do what it wants with your data. For example your IP is 
likely to not do anything when I make a request to it - you've not set up a 
web server . I could probably 'Ping' it to see if it's online, but that's 
about it. You aren't hosting a web page or hosting for the WWW - you are 
just online the Internet. Web servers will take your data, and return what 
you requested (if all goes well) sending it back through the networks, 
until it reaches your network. 'Routers' are what pass on or 'Route' it 
around.

They are generally all connected together with cables. Your data will 
travel down fibre optic cables at near to the speed of light when 
travelling across countries or any long distance, even under the sea. It 
would be very slow if it had to use satellites. I believe that's why 
connection speed on cruise ships is very slow - they use satellites to 
connect to the rest of the network.
http://www.fastcodesign.com/1671777/infographic-the-550000-miles-of-undersea-cabling-that-powers-the-internet

This is my understanding. Alas, I'm only 17 so I have much to learn. I 
tried to put this in Layman's terms although I had to use some specialist 
terms - feel free to look them up.

top_comment.text:
I've been wondering about the internet's future, and I want to know about 
it's eventual role in space. If the internet still exists by the time that 
we are settling other planets, would each one have their own networks? Or 
would they be one titanic system? Also, when we can eventually travel 
interstellar distances, do you think we will have some way to still 
communicate across the gap?﻿
top_comment.author: iliketrains0pwned

comments.text:
FYI, there already is work being done on deep space communication. NASA's 
Deep Space Network is a network of dishes and satellites which provide data 
connections to and from spacecrafts.

It's by no means the internet, but they are tackling some important issues 
regarding packet loss and delays of hours instead of milliseconds. On the 
normal internet, if a packet gets lost your computer will request a new one 
and probably get it within a second. In space that could take hours. So 
clearly our current protocols aren't suited very well to that kind of 
networks. It's really fighting against the laws of physics to get any kind 
of data back and forth reliably. The distances are simply unimaginable.

Part of the DSN is finding solutions to those issues so that spacecrafts 
can be controlled and send back meaningful data. When we eventually do 
settle on Mars or anywhere else, you can be sure that the data link between 
the planets will have a lot in common with the DSN.

On a personal note, I believe that the internet is a historic invention 
like fire. I like to see it as a kind of brain for the organism that is the 
human species. It allows absolutely anyone to exchange information with any 
other person. It's a goldmine of knowledge, information and improbable 
collaborations. It has already transformed out lives and I think it's only 
getting started. Back to the fire analogy: We've now learned how to cook 
meat and stay warm at night. I'm excited to find out what the combustion 
engine might look like ;)
comments.author: Niosus

comments.text:
I do believe the answer to all of those questions is 'yes'. All planets 
will have their own networks. These networks will be connected to a 
gigantic interstellar relay-system. It's the way information has been 
delivered since ancient times (small networks of mail-delivery by foot 
connected to each other via sailing ships or some-such).
 
I think we will first learn to send information through the vast distances 
of space before we manage to send people, because it is... well, easier. 
Much simpler to send streams of data rather than physical creatures. So no 
worries of your selfies being confined in Alpha Centauri and never reaching 
your buddies on mother Earth :)

comments.text:
What an interesting comment... Considering that this entire page is mostly 
text and must be read [unless converted, for the blind] and considering 
that there is not much in the world that we interact with on a human level 
that didn't begin as something written down...

Without going into the philosophical side of "written versus visual", I 
think it all boils-down to "everyone learns differently":
Some people are visual and cannot comfortably absorb something unless it 
utilizes images and graphs, and perhaps audio as well (being told something 
or hearing a lecture, a film/movie is best for them);
while some prefer rows and pages of words, text instructions, and perhaps 
even statistics and formulas, all written down to be read and absorbed that 
way.
I think it all means that Everyone Is Different.

Those who gravitate towards video (as movies or games) over text, are 
simply more apt to become artists (graphic or music), or similar more 
visual vocations, in my opinion.
comments.author: GameTipsAndMoreBlog

comments.text:
+WPPatriot, I'm not making a mistake there. If space were infinite already 
before it started expanding during the big bang, then it would be infinite 
now. If space were finite before expansion, then it would be finite now. 
This is because we've undergone (from what we have observed) a finite 
period of expansion. If something infinite grows, it's still infinite, but 
we can still measure the rate of growth. Likewise, if something is finite, 
and grows a finite amount, it's definitely still finite.

+Austin Macdade +Thetechgenius
Actually, no. The universe is definitely *finite*.
Apparently you've never studied relativity or cosmology. Einstein proved 
that, in order for space and time to exist, the universe must either be 
continually expanding or continually shrinking. At any given moment the 
universe has a definite size, and it merely curves back into itself, 
similarly to how traveling across the surface of a sphere will always 
return an observer to its starting position. There are no edges to the 
universe, but it is indeed a finite, expanding space.
comments.author: The Real Flenuan

comments.text:

 Exactly. The universe is indeed infinite. It goes on forever, just like 
numbers. Until someone proves different, then it only makes sense that the 
universe is infinite.

comments.text:
+The Real Flenuan, how do you arrive at the conclusion that the universe is 
not infinite? The evidence currently points at the universe being flat, 
space has a curvature of roughly 0, from what we can observe. Spacetime has 
non-zero curvature, but not space. Are you suggesting that we're living in 
a flat closed manifold? We haven't observed an edge yet, so that's the only 
hypothesis that I can come up with that would make sense.

top_comment.text:
I think text based information (e.g., books) requires greater stimulation 
of the brain's creative faculties since it requires the mind to imagine all 
the sensory information instead of having it provided directly as images or 
sounds. Although the internet contains text based information, it is 
largely driven by multimedia that is more directly stimulating to the 
senses, thus making the absorption of information a more passive act since 
it does not require imagination.

Furthermore, the "linearity" or "rigidity" of books requires a sense of 
discipline, as we have to coerce our ever shortening attention spans into 
maintaining focus on a particular subject in order to gain depth of 
knowledge, not breadth.﻿

comments.text:
And yet it is the rapid input of unrelated information within short periods 
of time that trains our mind to make connections between ideas that we 
would have never made before. Along with that is the ability to put 
ourselves in the content creator's shoes. Reading a book, we tend to view 
the author as some celebrity, someone we could never hope to actually talk 
to. We also are alone in our own mind while we read. But on the web, every 
piece of information comes with the ability to immediately discuss the 
topic with not only the author, but with completely random strangers under 
the shroud of anonymity, allowing us to bypass any and all social blocks we 
may have if we were talking face to face.
My reply to you is a perfect example of this. I don't know you, you don't

comments.text:
ExperienceLOS7713, I couldn't agree more. My son (18) is determined to 
persuade me that books are less stimulating for the brain than screen-based 
product. He asked me to watch this video and I replied as follows:
Yes, very interesting, although in my opinion the bit about books compared 
with screens is very superficial. The thing is that people read books and 
use screens for entirely different reasons; some people who do a lot of 
gaming also read a lot of books, and what they're looking for in one medium 
is entirely different from what they're looking in the other. They enjoy 
being 'in charge' of the narrative when using a screen, and they also enjoy 
being directed (and not necessarily in charge) when reading a book. So I 
think that the guy in the video is setting up a false comparison; books are 
not 'better' than screens, and screens are not 'better' than books - they 
fulfill different requirements. People who manage to benefit from books and 
screens are better off than people who only involve themselves with one or 
the other. He doesn't actually say that screens exercise the brain more 
than books, but he implies it - and what I would say is that some books no 
doubt exercise the brain a great deal and others not so much, if at all. 

However, I think he's wrong to say (or imply) that people who read books 
are being lead in a way that people playing sophisticated video games are 
not; this is too much of a generalisation; again, it depends on the book 
(and the screen activity). A great writer places an idea or an image before 
the reader, who will make something of it - and the range of things that 
can be made of a single idea or image can be vast. A great writer doesn't 
direct the reader and tell him what to think - he/she opens up the world to 
the reader, often through very inconspicuous details. A poor writer can't 
do this, and I imagine that people who read crappy books would indeed be 
better off spending their time on a screen. By the same token, some things 
that people absorb through screens will genuinely benefit them, while 
others won't. So I think that what this guy has to say at this point in the 
video simply isn't subtle enough. 

Also, I'm not sure what is meant, precisely, by 'exercise' for the brain. 
Whatever the positive/negative effects of either reading or 'screening', 
the fact is that one has to put more work into reading a demanding book (or 
perhaps any book) than into doing stuff on a screen. I would argue that the 
effort required to interpret the author's words is in some ways a bit like 
having to dig diamonds out of the earth a mile below the surface and in 
testing conditions, rather than simply finding them lying around on the 
surface, to be simply picked up and marvelled at. This process of 
intellectual 'mining' is what in my opinion makes many books more valuable 
as 'brain exercise' than most computer games or other screen activity. I'm 
not saying that all computer games/screen activity is less valuable than 
most books; just that, just as the vast majority of books are very 
rewarding, just as the vast majority of songs are not very rewarding, just 
as the vast majority of paintings are not very rewarding - so are the vast 
majority of computer games not very rewarding. Like all those books, songs 
and paintings, most computer games no doubt provide activity for the brain, 
but it's not necessarily very valuable activity.
comments.author: Clive Illman

comments.text:
That begs the question...... exercise our creativity (by learning through 
text-based) or more efficiently acquire the information through use of 
multimedia? Much of the time, I believe a hybrid is the best system we have 
now.

For instance, reading how an internal combustion engine or manual 
transmission works without pictures is futile. It would be a ridiculously 
slow and tedious process. Because it's such a complex, yet simple, piece of 
engineering, a multimedia-based system may be more tricky to absorb, 
because the viewer may not understand something at first and will have to 
go back multiple times.

Personally, I prefer a hybrid system. HowStuffWorks tends do have plenty of 
that, and it's generally very easy to learn how things work (although 
sometimes the media could be better or there could be more of it).

FYI Facebook can be considered part of the deep web for a large part. Are 
your posts only visible to friends and not everyone? If so, that's content 
on the web that search engines can never find. It's part of the deep web by 
any sensible definition. So is your webmail, Youtube subscription list (the 
one you see on the homepage) or Twitter feed. While Youtube videos and 
tweets generally are public, the list of videos and tweets you see can 
never be found or accessed by anyone else.

The Tor stuff people talk about is also part of the deep web, but it's a 
TINY fraction. If it wasn't so controversial it wouldn't be notable at all.

comments.text:
+Nishabtam A G Vayabari Eh, It's questionable and controversial because the 
stuff on it is what people are concerned about. Using the browser isn't 
generally a concern for any reason unless you go on your personal stuff, or 
simply browsing certain parts of the internet is a crime in your country. 
It's not advised to go on your personal things like Facebook on TOR, 
because that ruins the magic of being anonymous, those bits of information 
are sent to hundreds of computers, and you can be easily tracked from 
there. TOR has multiple uses. It is a hole used to access some parts of the 
deep web, or "darknet" and is also a way of keeping your anonymity. All of 
the information sent from your computer, is then sent to hundreds of 
computers through peer to peer connection before you reach your 
destination, which all of those bits of information sent are scrambled and 
then unscrambled when reaching the website you want to access, and then 
it's all sent back to you using the standard UDP and TCP protocols that the 
normal world wide web uses. The part that may be concerning is that the 
deep web has things on it that might not be suitable for viewing. One such 
example (that no longer exists today) is "The Silk Road" which was one of 
the largest online black markets that had ever existed before, where 
illegal guns, drugs, and even HITS, (hiring someone to kill another person) 
were sold in online bitcoin transactions. It's not exactly so "deep" 
because searches for it have expanded more and more to the surface of the 
web, and it's not exactly the secret thing you need to access a secret 
website anymore. TOR has proven that it's security can be cracked, which it 
has been by the NSA, and the owner of the silk road was arrested. Not only 
that, but other things have been proven. Many High ranking officials and 
FBI agents lurk TOR, and bait users to click on illegal sites like child 
porn or money printing services, which are tricks to track you down and 
have you arrested. Many of TOR's servers have been proven to simply be 
botnets and aren't actual people, but zombie computers. Now, the deep web 
requires common sense to navigate through. Don't go searching the deep web 
for illegal things, and don't be stupid, but simply browsing it and finding 
things that don't fit that criteria, and you'll be just fine.
The conclusion? Using TOR is completely fine. Your intentions define your 
experience. If you're just curious, and you play your cards right, you 
shouldn't find anything that can make you say "I've seen some shit" unless 
you were looking for it. If you're looking for illegal things, it could be 
legitimate, or it could be a high ranking official that would really like 
you in a jail cell. If you're looking to spam/harass people so you can 
change your IP and never be IP banned, it could work, and it's very 
unlikely you'll get into any serious trouble with it, but don't use your 
personal account, because you could compromise it to hackers looking for 
your information.

+Turtle Of Rage
There is no 'metaphysical realm' of science.  The scientific method 
requires factual, real, physical evidence to support any hypothesis.

Spirit 'science' isn't even good at metaphysics, and certainly fails at 
philosophy, as well.

out?  In which journals do they publish?

Science *does* have to be based on fact; it's part of the very method that 
gives science its name.  Without a need to back up an assertion with actual 
evidence, one can make up any sort of crazy b.s. - much as Jordan (of 
Spirit Science) does.

somehow meet them halfway?  There's even less merit to SS than to that 
hypothesis; at least they have the fact that there is an Earth on their

what?  Horseshit, perhaps?

Certainly not something that belongs on a respectable channel about science.

comments.text:
+tehfutureawesome Talking about evidence, you should have known that it 
means- in short- body of facts. After discussing so much about prove, you 
just end up saying that you don't need need it, so what can you rely on to 
tell right from wrong, truth from lie? A *lucky guess*?
In science, we don't see what we want to see. Instead, we try to see as 
much as we can see (investigating), and try to make the most from it 
(analyzing data). We never claim to have "the absolute truth", but we try 
to use everything accessible to us to get as close to the truth as we can. 
In science, we keep our minds open to what we haven't known, to all sorts 
of possibilities, but we simply don't accept any possibility to be true 
until we can test them. Like your example of black swan to Middle Age 
Europeans and my example of "atoms" to ancient Greeks, Multiverse to us 
today is still an untestable possibility, so we are not hurried to accept 
it yet. With all sorts of deities and supernatural stuff human has ever 
thought of (and even Hogwarts!), we say that they are *possible but 
improbable*, until someone can prove them. If you just believe in a certain 
possibility without any evidence and then it turns out out to be true, it 
means nothing but you have a *lucky guess*. Therefore, my friend, there's 
no need to rush into believing in any unproven claim. Make it slow. Let's 
wait and see what mystery scientists will conquer next.
comments.author: minha

comments.text:
+tehfutureawesome Your are contradicting yourself by stating "You can't 
truly prove something right, nor wrong." and then going on to the classical 
example of a falsifiable statement. I assume you agree that the statement 
"all swans are white" is *truly proven wrong*, or falsified by the 
observation of a black swan? Therefore, it was a scientific statement, 
elbeit an incorrect one. Being falsifiable is a property of scientific 
statements. All statements that can neither be proven right, neither be 
proven wrong are non-scientific, or pseudoscience. Also, it doesn't make 
any sense to debate such statements because the only "source" of these 
statements would be personal conviction (for whatever reason).

as much as in the old days". When the internet is full of writing and 
fanfiction websites, as well as digital book stores... not to mention the

makes text clearer and easier to manage. Books don't let you customize the

comments.text:
I feel that intellectualism is generally discouraged today, at least in a 
de facto sense. I saw someone sharing a potentially great idea, feeling 
discouraged about being relatively smart, and wanted to offer some sort of 
acceptance on a medium that is notoriously harsh.

On the boasting, I've felt that saying "I'm strong" is just a statement, 
but saying "I'm smart" is bragging. Like if someone posts pictures of 
themselves shirtless and fit, it seems regular, no one really minds; but 
if they posted pictures of all the 100s they earned on exams, that might be 
seen as bragging. I'm typically quite humble, but the perception is 
subjective -- Where I see reaching out, you see a boast. This is my 
opinion, and yours may differ, but I wanted to clarify myself.

  -Galen
comments.author: Galen Hall

comments.text:
Don't worry, I don't think it's stupid. I had a similar idea a long while 
back, but I love to think and be introspective. I've been "smarter" than 
almost everyone I've met, not that I'm particularly better (everyone has 
their strengths), but I've always learned much faster than those around me 
and just naturally try intellectually challenging things. My friends have 
started catching up after the years, and I love sharing ideas, but I see 
them coming up with their "own" ideas that I thought of many years ago, and 
have been thought of thousands of times by many people. It's a chain, a 
series, a progression that people make, and it's excellent if you have 
already thought of such so early on. Rock on man, don't let anyone tell you 
your thoughts are dumb, just keep thinking and questioning.

Take care,

  -Galen.
